_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This Risk Management Plan document  has been developed for AMPI located at 700 1st Street, Rochester, Minnesota. This document has been prepared to satisfy the following regulations:

Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.

The purpose of this document is to:

1. Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.

2. Assist AMPI and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.


This document summarizes AMPI?s administrative and operational programs to prevent chemical-related accidents and reduce potential risks. These programs are detailed in the facility?s Risk Management Program documentation.

The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is ammonia. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant for the purposes of cold storage and processing dairy food products.  AMPI, Incorporated is the owner and operator of the facility and the ammonia refrigeration system.

Documentation

The RMP document summarizes the prevention programs and technical studies that formulate the RMP at the facility for safe handling of ammonia. At the beginning of the RMP documents, are the Documentation Record and  Record of Revision, and Revision Page Summary forms. The Documentation Record outlines all parties that have a copy of the respective document. Updates to this document will be provided to all parties listed on this record. The Record of Revision form should be used to indicate that the revisions have been included. When revision pages are provided a Revision Page Summary will be provided that outlines each added or replaced. 
 
Executive Summary

The following sections are required by the EPA Risk Management Program regulation, 40 CFR Part 68. 

A. Accidental Release Prevention a

nd Emergency Response Policies

AMPI is dedicated to operation of a safe facility for its employees and neighboring community. A safety committee has been established that is responsible for the implementation of the safety program and an Emergency Response Plan.  This includes safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. AMPI has prepared risk and safety programs to ensure safe handling of the ammonia in the refrigeration system. Recently AMPI conducted a Process Hazard Analysis to identify potential hazards and the appropriate mitigation measures. 

B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

1. The AMPI facility is located at 700 1st Avenue S.E. in Rochester, Minnesota. The facility started operations at this location in 1943. At that time, ammonia was used as a refrigerant. The total quantity of ammonia in 2000 was calculated to be 17,816 pounds. 

2. The AMPI ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycle the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again. The system, consisting of piping, valves and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for product and process equipment. 

3. Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature: lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature. Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat. Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize. Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid. Typical operating conditions range from approximately 0 psig on the low pressure side of each system to 185 psig on the high side. 

4. Ammonia is the regulated substance at this facility.

5. The maximum inventory of ammonia at the facility is 26,500 pounds.

AMPI has an accidental release prevention progra

m in place which complies with OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management Standard. The International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's (IIAR) "Guide to the Implementation of Process Safety Management (PSM) for Ammonia Refrigeration" was used to implement the PSM program at the Facility. Parts of the program include.
1. Employee Participation
2. Process Safety Information
3. Process Safety Hazard Analysis (PHA)
4. Operating Procedures
5. Training
6. Contractor Requirements
7. Pre Start-up Safety Review
8. Mechanical Integrity Audits
9. Hot Work Permits
10. Management of Change
11. Incident Investigation
12. Emergency Planning and Response
13. Compliance Audits

Gartner Refrigeration & Mfg., Inc. of Minneapolis, MN was (and continues to be) used to help implement the facility's PSM program, including: system audits, PHA development, and employee training. Gartner Refrigeration also performs maintenance on the refrigeration system. The refrigeration system remains in good condition as a result of the maintenance program used by AMPI and Gartner.
